title: Eliahu Inbal
text:
Eliahu Inbal (born 16 February 1936, <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>) is an Israeli <a href="conducting">conductor</a>.
Inbal studied <a href="violin">violin</a> at the <a href="Israeli%20Academy%20of%20Music">Israeli Academy of Music</a> and took composition lessons with <a href="Paul%20Ben-Haim">Paul Ben-Haim</a>. Upon hearing him there, <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a> endorsed a scholarship for Inbal to study conducting at the <a href="Conservatoire%20de%20Paris">Conservatoire de Paris</a>, and he also took courses with <a href="Sergiu%20Celibidache">Sergiu Celibidache</a> and <a href="Franco%20Ferrara">Franco Ferrara</a> in <a href="Hilversum">Hilversum</a>, <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>. At <a href="Novara">Novara</a>, he won first prize at the <a href="Cantelli%20Awards">1963 Guido Cantelli conducting competition</a> at the age of 26. Since after that, Eliahu Inbal has enjoyed a career of international renown, conducting leading orchestras around the world. <a href="https%3A//aicf.org/artist/eliahu-inbal/"></a>
Inbal made most of his early appearances in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, but a successful British debut in 1965 with the <a href="London%20Philharmonic">London Philharmonic</a> led to a number of other engagements with British orchestras. He subsequently worked with a number of orchestras throughout Europe and in America, and eventually took joint <a href="British%20citizenship">British citizenship</a>.
From 1974 to 1990, he was the principal conductor of the <a href="hr-Sinfonieorchester">Frankfurt Radio Symphony Orchestra</a> in <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>. With them, he was the first to record the original versions of several of <a href="Anton%20Bruckner">Anton Bruckner</a>'s symphonies, for which he won the "Jahrespreis der deutschen Schallplatten-Kritik". He also has recorded two complete cycles each of the symphonies of <a href="Gustav%20Mahler">Gustav Mahler</a> and <a href="Dmitri%20Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a>. From 1984 to 1989, he was chief conductor at <a href="La%20Fenice">La Fenice</a> in <a href="Venice">Venice</a>. From 2003 to 2011, he conducted a series of the complete symphonies of Bruckner at the <a href="Rheingau%20Musik%20Festival">Rheingau Musik Festival</a> with the <a href="WDR%20Symphony%20Orchestra%20Cologne">WDR Symphony Orchestra Cologne</a>, concluding with the unfinished <a href="Symphony%20No.%209%20%28Bruckner%29">Ninth Symphony</a>. He was appointed music director of La Fenice in January, 2007.
From 2009 to 2012, Inbal served as the chief conductor of the <a href="Czech%20Philharmonic">Czech Philharmonic</a>. Inbal also served as the principal conductor of the <a href="Tokyo%20Metropolitan%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Tokyo Metropolitan Symphony Orchestra</a> from 2008 to 2014, and currently is the Conductor Laureate of the orchestra.
Currently, Inbal is the chief conductor of the <a href="Taipei%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Taipei Symphony Orchestra</a> since August 2019, with a contract of three years.
Inbal has conducted a wide variety of works. He is best known for his interpretations of <a href="Romantic%20music">late-Romantic</a> works, but is also noted as an <a href="opera">opera</a> conductor, and has given the premieres of a number of modern works.
